author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: David Bowie’s son accepts Brit Awards honor on behalf of dad
text:
David Bowie’s posthumous award show dominance continued when his “Blackstar” won Album of the Year at the Brit Awards Wednesday.
His son, filmmaker Duncan Jones, accepted the award on his father’s behalf.
“I lost my dad last year, but I also became a dad and I was spending a lot of time, after getting over the shock, of trying to work out what would I want my son to know about his granddad,” Jones said.
“And I think it would be the same thing that most of my dad's fans have taken over the last 50 years: That he's always been there supporting people who think they're a little bit weird or a little bit strange. A little bit different. And he's always been there for them. So this award is for all the kooks and all the people who make the kooks.”
Bowie died on Jan. 10, 2016, two days after his 69th birthday, after a battle with liver cancer.
Michael C. Hall, who starred in Bowie’s musical “Lazarus,” accepted the “Changes” singer’s award for Best Male Solo Artist.
“This award is for all the kooks and all the people who make the kooks,” Jones said. (JUSTIN TALLIS/AFP/Getty Images) 
“If David Bowie could be here tonight, he probably wouldn't be here tonight. But since he can't be here tonight, I’m here tonight on his behalf and on behalf of his family to accept this testament to a man beholden to nothing but his own boundless imagination and daring, whose ever-expanding artistic vitality simultaneously soothes us and sears us and astonishes us," Hall said.
"Maybe he is here tonight? I don’t know. But I’m honored to stand before you and acknowledge the potency of his work and, if I may, also acknowledge that David’s kindness and generosity and enthusiasm will forever inspire me to be a better man on his behalf.”
